story.text: LONDON Jan 3 The FTSE 100 .FTSE index of Britain's leading shares nosed down 0.05 percent in early trading on Wednesday, with miners falling after a strong sector performance on Tuesday, led down by Vedanta Resources (VED.L). Precious metal prices and most base metal prices edged up, but this failed to prevent a sector decline. Vedanta Resources (VED.L) fell 2.7 percent while Xstrata XTA.L and Antofagasta (ANTO.L) each slipped about 2 percent. "The mining stocks got squeezed up yesterday, and they are giving up the gains they made then," said a market maker. By 0837 GMT, the FTSE 100 index fell 3.8 points, to 6,307.1. Economic data from the U.S. including on manufacturing, construction spending and jobs, will provide a steer on the health of the country's economy, which may influence UK stocks, traders said. The Federal Open Market Committee minutes due after the close at 1900 GMT will come too late to have impact on the UK market on Wednesday, traders said. "The U.S. market will for once be playing catch up with European markets because it was closed yesterday," said a trader. Heavyweight oil stocks were mixed after oil prices held below $61 a barrel as mild weather conditions were projected to persist in the U.S., undermining heating oil demand. Royal Dutch Shell (RDSa.L) fell 0.1 percent but BP (BP.L) rose 0.3 percent. A UBS sector comment note boosted the banking sector. Key picks were Barclays (BARC.L), which rose 0.7 percent, and RBS (RBS.L), which rose 0.4 percent after UBS said it was the cheapest large bank anywhere. Among the least favoured stocks by UBS was Northern Rock NRK.L, which slipped 0.1 percent. HSBC Holdings (HSBA.L) gained 0.3 percent on news that the banking group had appointed Simon Robertson, a City of London adviser, to be its leading non-executive director. Among media stocks, British satellite broadcaster BSkyB BSY.L rose 0.2 percent on news it is to launch a video-on-demand service and develop its Sky+ digital recorder to boost its pay TV offering in 2007.
story.title: ftse down , miners fall , led down by xstrata
